prompt: 83yo M bronch. dx J95.811 Postprocedural pneumothorax. cleaned out Right Mainstem, Bronchus Intermedius, and Left Mainstem. bal done at Lingula, 50cc in 15cc back. bx at Left Mainstem spur. dr Dr. Ross attending.
completion:
DATE OF PROCEDURE: [Date] CC Referred Physician: Patel

INDICATION FOR OPERATION The patient is a 83-year-old male who presents with lung transplant and airway narrowing.
The nature, purpose, risks, benefits, and alternatives to bronchoscopy were discussed with the patient in detail.
The patient wished to proceed and informed consent was obtained. 

CONSENT Obtained before the procedure.
Indications, potential complications, and alternatives were discussed with the patient or surrogate.
The consent was signed and witnessed by an assisting medical professional.

PREOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS

J95.811 Postprocedural pneumothorax

POSTOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS

J95.811 Postprocedural pneumothorax

PROCEDURE

Therapeutic aspiration (initial episode)

Diagnostic bronchoscopy with Bronchoalveolar Lavage (BAL)

Endobronchial Biopsy(s)

ATTENDING Dr. Ross

ASSISTANT PA Thompson

SUPPORT STAFF RN: Jessica RN RT: Chris RT

ANESTHESIA General Anesthesia

MONITORING Pulse oximetry, heart rate, telemetry, and blood pressure were continuously monitored by an independent trained observer throughout the procedure.
INSTRUMENTATION Disposable Bronchoscope

ESTIMATED BLOOD LOSS None

COMPLICATIONS None

PROCEDURE IN DETAIL After the successful induction of anesthesia, a timeout was performed confirming patient identity, planned procedures, and laterality.
Therapeutic Aspiration Successful therapeutic aspiration was performed to clean out the Right Mainstem, Bronchus Intermedius, and Left Mainstem from mucus.
Bronchoalveolar Lavage (BAL) BAL was performed in the Lingula (LB4/LB5) with saline instilled and returned.
Specimens were submitted. Instilled 50 cc of NS, suction returned with 15 cc of NS.
Samples sent for Cell Count, Microbiology (Cultures/Viral/Fungal), and Cytology. 

Endobronchial Biopsy Endobronchial biopsies were obtained with hemostasis achieved.
Tissue was submitted for pathology. No immediate bleeding was observed. Performed at Left Mainstem spur. Lesion was successfully removed.
Samples sent for Microbiology (Cultures/Viral/Fungal) and Pathology. 

The patient tolerated the procedure well. There were no immediate complications.
At the conclusion of the operation, the patient was extubated in the operating room and transported to the recovery room in stable condition.
SPECIMENS

BAL (Lingula) — Cell Count, Microbiology, Cytology

Endobronchial Biopsy (Left Mainstem spur) — Microbiology, Pathology

IMPRESSION / PLAN

83-year-old male who presents for bronchoscopy for airway stenosis.
Follow-up BAL performed.

Airway noted to be in good condition.

Plan for repeat bronchoscopy in 4-6 weeks.

INDICATION FOR OPERATION The patient is a 34-year-old male who presents with surveillance post-lung transplant.

Therapeutic aspiration (initial episode)

Diagnostic bronchoscopy with Bronchoalveolar Lavage (BAL)

Endobronchial Biopsy(s)

ATTENDING Dr. Al-Fayed

ASSISTANT Dr. Jacobs

SUPPORT STAFF RN: David RN RT: Tom RT

ANESTHESIA General Anesthesia

MONITORING Pulse oximetry, heart rate, telemetry, and blood pressure were continuously monitored by an independent trained observer throughout the procedure.
INSTRUMENTATION Disposable Bronchoscope

ESTIMATED BLOOD LOSS None

COMPLICATIONS None

PROCEDURE IN DETAIL After the successful induction of anesthesia, a timeout was performed confirming patient identity, planned procedures, and laterality.
Therapeutic Aspiration Successful therapeutic aspiration was performed to clean out the Trachea and Main Carina from mucus.
Bronchoalveolar Lavage (BAL) BAL was performed in the Lingula (LB4/LB5) with saline instilled and returned.
Specimens were submitted. Instilled 100 cc of NS, suction returned with 40 cc of NS.
Samples sent for Cell Count, Microbiology (Cultures/Viral/Fungal), and Cytology. 

Endobronchial Biopsy Endobronchial biopsies were obtained with hemostasis achieved.
Tissue was submitted for pathology. No immediate bleeding was observed. Performed at Anastomosis site. Lesion was successfully removed.
Samples sent for Microbiology (Cultures/Viral/Fungal) and Pathology. 

The patient tolerated the procedure well. There were no immediate complications.
At the conclusion of the operation, the patient was extubated in the operating room and transported to the recovery room in stable condition.
SPECIMENS

BAL (Lingula) — Cell Count, Microbiology, Cytology

Endobronchial Biopsy (Anastomosis site) — Microbiology, Pathology

IMPRESSION / PLAN

34-year-old male who presents for bronchoscopy for airway stenosis.
Follow-up BAL performed.

Airway noted to be in good condition.

Plan for repeat bronchoscopy in as needed.

We also did a BAL in the Lateral Segment of RML (RB4) and Medial Segment of RML (RB5) and a biopsy of the Right Upper Lobe orifice. Return interval is as needed.
completion:
DATE OF PROCEDURE: [Date] CC Referred Physician: Smith

INDICATION FOR OPERATION The patient is a 52-year-old male who presents with persistent cough and lung opacity.
The nature, purpose, risks, benefits, and alternatives to bronchoscopy were discussed with the patient in detail.
The patient wished to proceed and informed consent was obtained. 

CONSENT Obtained before the procedure.
Indications, potential complications, and alternatives were discussed with the patient or surrogate.
The consent was signed and witnessed by an assisting medical professional.

PREOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS

J98.09 Other diseases of bronchus, not elsewhere classified

POSTOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS

J98.09 Other diseases of bronchus, not elsewhere classified

PROCEDURE

Therapeutic aspiration (initial episode)

Diagnostic bronchoscopy with Bronchoalveolar Lavage (BAL)

Endobronchial Biopsy(s)

ATTENDING Dr. Ross

ASSISTANT Dr. Jacobs

SUPPORT STAFF RN: Sarah RN RT: Tom RT

ANESTHESIA General Anesthesia

MONITORING Pulse oximetry, heart rate, telemetry, and blood pressure were continuously monitored by an independent trained observer throughout the procedure.
INSTRUMENTATION Disposable Bronchoscope

ESTIMATED BLOOD LOSS None

COMPLICATIONS None

PROCEDURE IN DETAIL After the successful induction of anesthesia, a timeout was performed confirming patient identity, planned procedures, and laterality.
Therapeutic Aspiration Successful therapeutic aspiration was performed to clean out the Right Middle Lobe and Lingula from mucus.
Bronchoalveolar Lavage (BAL) BAL was performed in the Lateral Segment of RML (RB4) and Medial Segment of RML (RB5) with saline instilled and returned.
Specimens were submitted. Instilled 80 cc of NS, suction returned with 35 cc of NS.
Samples sent for Cell Count, Microbiology (Cultures/Viral/Fungal), and Cytology. 

Endobronchial Biopsy Endobronchial biopsies were obtained with hemostasis achieved.
Tissue was submitted for pathology. No immediate bleeding was observed. Performed at Right Upper Lobe orifice. Lesion was successfully removed.
Samples sent for Microbiology (Cultures/Viral/Fungal) and Pathology. 

The patient tolerated the procedure well. There were no immediate complications.
At the conclusion of the operation, the patient was extubated in the operating room and transported to the recovery room in stable condition.
SPECIMENS

BAL (Lateral Segment of RML) — Cell Count, Microbiology, Cytology

Endobronchial Biopsy (Right Upper Lobe orifice) — Microbiology, Pathology

IMPRESSION / PLAN

52-year-old male who presents for bronchoscopy for airway stenosis.
Follow-up BAL performed.

Airway noted to be in good condition.

Plan for repeat bronchoscopy in as needed.
